subject: RE: regional accents
msgSnippet: I personally wouldn t want to see any standardized spelling. The current guidelines are well thought out. My view is that learning to quickly identify
messageBody:
I personally wouldn't want to see any standardized spelling. The current guidelines are well thought out. My view is that learning to quickly identify different spellings is a good thing.


I decided to learn the alphabet for note taking and diary entries, some "cryptic" text on some art work as well as the joy of casual calligraphy in a beautiful alphabet.


Reading the different stories rendered in the alphabet reminded me of some great debates I had with my late mother who insisted on the use of "proper" English as if the language was codified and immovable.


Quickscript clearly reveals a language in a constant state of change and the strength of quickscript is that it is an excellent vehicle to support the evolution.



---In read_alphabet@yahoogroups.com, <bonusfrogs@...> wrote:


On Nov 10, 2013, at 2:21 AM, weshdim@... wrote:



I've been spending a little time over the last few days learning QuickScript. I've also started reading some of the stories rendered in the script like Cthulhu, Alice's Adventures and The Art of War.


Some times I haven't been able to make out a word here and there but after some effort realize I'm reading, not only a new alphabet, but also someone's accent. For example, the word for "professor" from Cthulhu, took a while to decipher, and I originally thought it must have been a spelling error.

At least in my copy of Cthulhu, I've changed "professor" to [prəˈfɛsɚ], although that isn't what it started out as. I think it was [pɚˈfɛsɚ] when I started.

Once I realized I was reading American pronunciation, things fell into place. (My accent is Australian.)

Are there still any other Americanisms that you noticed? I probably need to change "with" so it uses [ð] instead of [θ]…

Regional accents really creep in with regards to the choice of vowels and diphthongs.

This is not a criticism, just something I didn't quite expect.

I hear ya. Read's spelling of "leisure" in the pangram on page 11 of the manual threw me for a loop, albeit briefly; I pronounce it so it rhymes with "seizure", not "pleasure".
